DOCNAME: CASE OF STERE AND OTHERS v. ROMANIA
CONCLUSION: Violation of P1-1;Inadmissible under Art. 6-1;Non-pecuniary damage - financial award;Costs and expenses (domestic proceedings) - claim dismissed
TEXT: CARDINAL . The applicants were born in DATE , DATE and DATE respectively and live in Alba Iulia .

CARDINAL . In connection with the restructuring of the armed forces , which had begun in DATE , a number of legislative measures were passed with a view to encouraging professional soldiers to apply for reassignment to the reserve force and thereby to take early retirement .

CARDINAL . In addition to their retirement pension , section CARDINAL of Government Ordinance no . CARDINAL of CARDINAL DATE ( “ Ordinance no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL ” ) granted those concerned a tax - free “ income replacement allowance ” calculated in relation to their gross DATE pay . Under section CARDINAL ( CARDINAL ) of PERSON no . CARDINAL of DATE ( “ Law no . CARDINAL ” ) , they were additionally entitled to a tax - free “ maintenance allowance ” , also calculated in relation to their gross DATE pay . The method of calculating those allowances was amended by Government Emergency Ordinance no . CARDINAL of DATE ( “ Ordinance no . CARDINAL ” ) , which provided that the net DATE pay would be used as the basis of calculation .

CARDINAL . At their request , the applicants were assigned to the reserve force and thereby took early retirement , on DATE for the first and third , and on DATE for the second , with entitlements to the above - mentioned pension and allowances . However , when those sums were paid out , ORG deducted income tax , calculated in accordance with Ordinance no . CARDINAL of CARDINAL DATE concerning income tax ( “ Ordinance no . CARDINAL ” ) , thereby depriving the first applicant of CARDINAL NORP lei ( ROL ) , the second of ROL CARDINAL,CARDINAL,CARDINAL and the third of ROL CARDINAL,CARDINAL,CARDINAL .

CARDINAL . In an action against ORG , the applicants claimed the reimbursement of those sums , which they alleged had been wrongfully deducted , on the ground that their allowances were exempt from tax under Ordinance no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL and PERSON no . ORG . ORG disputed their claim , contending that the taxation in question was consistent with Ordinance no . ORG .

CARDINAL . In a judgment of DATE ORG allowed the applicants’ action and ordered the Ministry to reimburse the amounts deducted for tax . The court considered that on the date of their retirement , that is to say some time before the entry into force of Ordinance no . CARDINAL , the applicants had acquired an entitlement to tax - free allowances calculated in relation to their gross DATE pay . Moreover , the court observed that section CARDINAL of Ordinance no . CARDINAL provided that maintenance allowances were likewise tax exempt .

CARDINAL . ORG appealed , arguing that the tax exemption provision in respect of the income replacement allowance , under section CARDINAL of Ordinance no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL , had been expressly repealed by section CARDINAL of Ordinance no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL , which had also implicitly abolished the exemption in respect of maintenance allowances under section CARDINAL ( CARDINAL ) of PERSON no . ORG .
CARDINAL . In a final decision of DATE ORG upheld the merits of the judgment at first instance on the following grounds :

“ Even assuming , purely for the sake of argument , that the provisions of section CARDINAL of Ordinance no . DATE had been repealed , those of LAW ( CARDINAL ) of PERSON no . DATE which also provide for tax exemption and for the calculation [ of the allowance ] in relation to gross DATE pay DATE would remain as a legal basis . ORG contends that the provision in question was implicitly repealed , but that view has not been substantiated , because Ordinance no . ORG post - dates PERSON no . ORG and if the legislature had wished to repeal the section in question , nothing would have prevented it from making express provision to that effect , as was the case for other legislative instruments referred to in section CARDINAL of Ordinance no . CARDINAL . ... In any event , a Government Ordinance , being of secondary legislative importance in relation to statute law , can not repeal a statute .

In addition , the ORG wrongly contends that Ordinance no . ORG constitutes a lex specialis in relation to Ordinance no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL and to Law no . CARDINAL . In actual fact , Ordinance no . ORG is the framework instrument concerning taxation , and , in relation to the other CARDINAL instruments mentioned above , which grant tax relief to a specific category of employees , it lays down the ordinary rules from which the special provisions of those instruments derogate .

Moreover , section CARDINAL of Ordinance no . CARDINAL states that income replacement allowances and maintenance allowances , such as those concerned in the present case , are exempt from income tax , thus indicating the legislature ’s intention that they should not be taxable .

The provisions of Ordinance no . CARDINAL to the effect that the allowance is calculated in relation to net pay do not apply in the case of the applicants , who retired before the entry into force of the LAW , which does not have retrospective effect ... The possibility of discrimination [ between servicemen who retired after the entry into force of Ordinance no . CARDINAL , whose allowances were calculated in relation to net pay , and those who retired before that date , who were entitled to allowances based on gross pay ] is not left to the discretion of the employer or of the courts , but is a matter for the legislature , which should have taken this into account and found an appropriate solution in the course of the legislative process , by means of precise and specific regulatory provisions . Accordingly , neither an employer nor a court can substitute itself for the legislature in harmonising the various provisions which have come into force at different times but which concern situations that are similar , although they arose , changed or ceased to exist under different statutes . ”

CARDINAL . NORP The court also considered that the CARDINAL allowances in issue could not be characterised as a “ salary ” or “ income treated as a salary ” for the purposes of sections CARDINAL and CARDINAL of Ordinance no . CARDINAL , especially as they were not included among the forms of taxable income referred to in section CARDINAL of that GPE .
Lastly , the court looked at the practice of other courts in similar disputes and found that it supported the claims of the former servicemen .
CARDINAL . As the judgment of DATE had become res judicata and had been endorsed with a writ of execution , the applicants received , on an unspecified date , the amounts they had claimed .
CARDINAL . On DATE the Procurator - General of GPE applied to ORG to have the DATE judgment of ORG and DATE decision of the ORG quashed .

CARDINAL . He considered that in construing domestic law the CARDINAL courts had committed serious errors of law which had vitiated the settlement of the dispute . He argued that section CARDINAL of Ordinance no . CARDINAL had superseded the provisions of LAW no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL and LAW CARDINAL of PERSON no . ORG , and added that under sections CARDINAL and CARDINAL of Ordinance no . ORG the allowances and other entitlements of military personnel were treated as salaries and were therefore liable to the taxation provided for in that Ordinance .

CARDINAL . The applicants sought the dismissal of the Procurator - General ’s application to have the judgments quashed , disputing his arguments that the above - mentioned provisions had been superseded and that the allowances were treated as salaries . They argued that , in any event , even assuming that the allowances could have been treated as salaries , they should not have been liable to tax , since section CARDINAL ( f ) of Ordinance no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL exempted from tax any allowances that were calculated in relation to net DATE pay . Moreover , under section CARDINAL ( CARDINAL ) of that GPE , net earnings were not defined as gross earnings minus tax but as gross earnings minus social - insurance contributions . Accordingly , they considered that ORG had wrongly deducted tax from their allowances .

CARDINAL . In a judgment of DATE ORG allowed the Procurator - General ’s application , quashed the impugned judgments and ordered the reimbursement of the sums that ORG had paid to the applicants on the basis of those judgments . The relevant passage of the decision provided :

“ Whilst section CARDINAL of Law no . ORG provides that , upon their reassignment to the reserve force , servicemen benefit from a tax - free maintenance allowance , calculated in relation to their gross DATE pay , that provision must be read in the light of the provisions of section CARDINAL of Government Ordinance no . CARDINAL and of ORG [ no . DATE – “ Order no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL ” ] , which , whilst providing that income from maintenance allowances is exempt from tax , specify which forms of income are included in that category and exclude any salaries or income treated as such .

Considering that Law no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL pertains precisely to salaries and entitlements relating to the status of ORG employee , it is clear that the grant of a maintenance allowance under LAW of the above - mentioned PERSON stems from employee status , and that such allowances are accordingly liable to tax , in accordance with Ordinance no . ORG .

That conclusion is confirmed by Government Order no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL which , referring to LAW no . CARDINAL , specifies what forms of income are exempt from tax , among them maintenance allowances . It can be seen from the enumeration in that provision that the maintenance allowances contemplated in Ordinance no . CARDINAL are confined to those granted for special purposes , such as maintenance allowances for soldiers’ spouses , welfare benefits , emergency relief granted by the ORG or local councils in cases of hardship , funeral grants , etc .
The above - mentioned provision makes no reference to maintenance allowances paid to servicemen upon their reassignment to the reserve force and calculated in relation to their gross DATE pay .
Consequently , since such allowances are comparable to a salary and are calculated on the basis of gross DATE pay , they are taxable like any gross income .

In addition , section CARDINAL of Ordinance no . ORG expressly provides that any provision contrary to that Ordinance is superseded , thereby confirming once again that the legislature ’s intention was to render such income taxable .

As regards the income replacement allowances granted to the applicants under LAW no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL , being tax - exempt and likewise calculated in relation to gross DATE pay , it should be noted that section DATE of Ordinance no . CARDINAL expressly superseded that provision as regards the tax exemption of such income . Accordingly , the applicants are also liable for tax on such income .

Furthermore , it is to be observed that section CARDINAL ( f ) of Ordinance no . ORG exempts from income tax only those income replacement allowances and maintenance allowances that are calculated in relation to net DATE pay , whereas the allowances granted to the applicants were calculated in relation to their gross DATE pay . It follows that this income was also taxable . ”
CARDINAL . As the authorities failed to bring any action for the enforcement of the judgment of ORG , the applicants have not , to date , reimbursed the disputed amounts .
CARDINAL . Article CARDINAL of the Code of Civil Procedure provided :
“ The Procurator - General may , of his own motion or on an application by the Minister of ORG , apply to ORG for any final judicial decision to be quashed on any of the following grounds :
CARDINAL . NORP that the court in question has exceeded its jurisdiction ;
CARDINAL . NORP that the decision concerned by the application has seriously breached the law , leading to erroneous findings on the merits of the case , or that the decision is ill - founded . ”
This Article was repealed by Government Emergency Ordinance no . CARDINAL of DATE .
CARDINAL . The relevant provisions read as follows :

“ During the restructuring of the armed forces , officers , non - commissioned officers and instructors [ having completed DATE of service ] may request to be reassigned to the reserve force , before reaching the statutory age - limit , with a military pension entitlement ... ”

“ Military personnel reassigned to the reserve force who are entitled to a military pension ... shall receive , in return for their service in the armed forces , the compensation provided for in the statutory provisions on remuneration of military personnel . Moreover , for DATE of service until DATE , they shall be entitled to a tax - free income replacement allowance of which the amount shall be double that of their last gross DATE pay . ”

“ Military personnel having completed DATE of service may request to be reassigned to the reserve force or may be assigned thereto automatically ... and shall receive a tax - free income replacement allowance , calculated on the basis of their length of service and their last gross DATE pay . ”
CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL of Law no . CARDINAL provides :

“ Military personnel reassigned to the reserve force who are entitled to a military pension , ... shall receive a tax - free maintenance allowance calculated according to their length of service ... and their last gross DATE pay ...

Military personnel reassigned to the reserve force , with a military pension entitlement , before reaching the statutory age - limit , shall also receive , for DATE of service until DATE , a tax - free maintenance allowance of which the amount shall be double that of their last gross DATE pay .
The provisions of the second paragraph shall not apply to military personnel receiving the income replacement allowance provided for by Ordinance no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL . ”
